In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Bhutan has requested support from the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to develop and install a revenue administration management information system (RAMIS) 
and to conduct a study on revenue policies and related regulatory frameworks. A consultation 
mission in November 2010 and a fact-finding mission in June 2011 formulated the goals and 
strategies of the proposed technical assistance (TA) and designed its corresponding activities. 
Extensive discussion with the government resulted in agreement on the purpose and outputs of 
the  TA  and  its  methodology,  key  activities,  implementation  arrangements,  design  and 
monitoring framework (Appendix 1), cost estimates (Appendix 2), and terms of reference for 
consultants (Appendix 3).1 
 
2.  The TA supports the government’s priorities as outlined in its 10th Five-Year Plan, 
2008–2013, which identified the importance of deepening the government’s self-reliance for 
financing development activities in the country and ensuring that domestic resources fund a 
larger share of the development outlay.2 The government seeks to introduce measures to 
increase revenue more quickly than expenditure in the next 5 years. Revised revenue estimates 
indicate that total government revenue for FY2010 is Nu14,049.0 million, of which tax revenue is 
Nu6,482.4  million  (10.5%  of  gross  domestic  product  [GDP])  and  nontax  revenue  is 
Nu7,566.6 million (12.2% of GDP).3 
 
3.  The TA will boost government revenue by expanding the revenue base and increasing 
the outreach of revenue collection. ADB mission findings make it evident that national income 
sources have not been adequately and efficiently tapped. In this respect, the Department of 
Revenue and Customs (DRC) urgently needs support to strengthen revenue administration with 
the goal of augmenting government revenue in the face of continued budget deficits and debt-
servicing requirements. Greater revenue  mobilization will pave the  way for expanding and 
improving service delivery across the economy. 
 
4.  The TA is in line with the Bhutan country partnership strategy, which seeks to improve 
development effectiveness by strengthening economic management and facilitating the launch 
of a robust monitoring and evaluation system.4 Although the TA was not included in the strategy, 
the government has asked ADB to provide it. ADB Management approved the concept paper for 
the TA on 29 April 2011. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Bhutan has demonstrated strong economic growth in the past decade, including average 
GDP growth of 7% since 2004. Per capita gross national income has almost tripled from $730 
per year in 2000 to $1,900 in 2008. Bhutan’s economic outlook remains promising in the short to 
medium term under the government’s development agenda, which is based on democratization 
and decentralization. The robust outlook is also premised on additional hydropower projects 
serving as engines for growth. 
 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 10 August 2011. 
2  Royal Government of Bhutan, Gross National Happiness Commission. 2009. Tenth Five-Year Plan, 2008–2013. 
For the 10th plan, the target for domestic resources is to cover 52% of the total plan outlay; in the 8th and 9th plans 
domestic resources were sufficient to fund only 30%–40% of the outlay. 
3   ADB. 2010. Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific, 2010. Manila.   
4  ADB. 2005. Country Partnership Strategy: Bhutan, 2006–2010. Manila; ADB. 2010. Country Operations Business 
  Plan: Bhutan, 2011–2013. Manila (Appendix 1).

2     
6.  Bhutan’s transition to parliamentary democracy in 2008 was facilitated in part by prudent 
economic  management  and  strong  economic  growth,  backed  by  an  improved  asset  base 
(driven by hydropower sector development), continuing poverty reduction, and better social 
indicators. Under the 10th plan, Bhutan pursues a wide-ranging development agenda to reduce 
poverty by revitalizing industry, enhancing infrastructure, balancing regional development, and 
fostering private sector growth. The challenge is to achieve the development goals by spending 
more on development while sustaining macroeconomic stability and fiscal balance. 
 
7.  The fiscal deficit has risen because of higher development spending to meet the goals of 
the 10th plan and recent wage increases. The FY2011 budget envisages a sharp increase in 
the fiscal deficit—to 7.6% of GDP—and a significant reduction in the current operating surplus. 
This deterioration in the overall fiscal position reflects significantly higher current spending 
because of (i) the 35% hike in civil servants’ wages, (ii) an increase in expenditure on goods 
and services, (iii) a jump in capital spending, and (iv) stagnant domestic revenue. In 2010, 
government expenditure increased to 40% of GDP (compared with 36% in 2005); it is expected 
to increase further in 2011 because of considerable capital spending on hydropower and higher 
civil servants’ wages.5 Given the wide and increasing gap between expenditure and tax revenue, 
debt in 2010 is expected to be about 4.8% of GDP, from close to 0% in 2008 and 2009, 
according to budgetary estimates. In Bhutan, direct and indirect taxes6 contribute about 46% of 
total  government  revenue,  with  corporate  income  tax  the  main  contributor.7  The  DRC  is 
responsible  for  collecting  these  taxes.  Recently,  the  DRC  developed  several  applications, 
including  a  tax  management  system,  revenue  administration  system,  and  sales  tax 
administration system, for collection of taxpayer data and taxpayer numbers. However, because 
these different systems are managed manually, the DRC seeks to establish a web-based 
revenue administration management information system that can integrate them. 
 
8.  In the medium term, the challenge is to limit debt while pursuing the 10th plan goals. 
Although the need to contain current spending at or below domestic revenue poses important 
fiscal restraints, both revenue and expenditure reforms are necessary to limit domestic financing, 
to avoid potential crowding out of private investment and building up of the already high public 
debt. To address these fiscal constraints, the government has agreed to pursue fiscal and tax 
reforms.  On  the  expenditure  side,  the  government  is  committed  to  prioritizing spending in 
sectors such as hydropower and tourism because they will account for a major share of future 
government revenue. On the revenue side, the government proposes to introduce a value-
added  tax,  rationalize  indirect  tax  rates,  and  improve  tax  administration.  Harmonization  of 
personal, business, and corporate income tax rates is also under consideration.8 
 
9.  To  meet  these  challenges,  the  TA  will  help  the  government  strengthen  revenue 
administration and build capacity to enhance efficiency and effectiveness in revenue collection. 
The TA will also help the DRC to work in a more integrated manner with the public accounts 
system and to generate the status of the government’s fund position on a real-time basis. The 
TA will conduct a study of revenue policies and regulatory frameworks for broadening the 
revenue base and streamlining administration.  
 
 
                                                 
5  Government revenue (tax and nontax) rose from about 10% of GDP in FY2005 to about 11% in FY2009. 
6  The direct tax includes corporate income tax, business income tax, personal income tax, motor vehicle tax, 
business and professional licenses, foreign travel tax, municipal tax, health contribution, and royalties. The indirect 
tax includes sales tax, excise duty, and customs duty. 
7  National Revenue Report (2008–2009), Contribution to government revenue: corporate income tax (16.6%), excise 
duty (7.4%), sales tax (6.5%), royalties (5.4%), business income tax (4.0%). 
8  ADB,  the  International  Monetary  Fund,  and  other  international  organizations  agree  on  the  need  for  a 
comprehensive fiscal reform program to meet the challenges of public financial management facing Bhutan.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be enhanced fiscal space9 to implement the government’s 10th and 11th 
5-year plans. This impact will be measured by an increase in the ratio of tax revenue to GDP. 
The outcome will be greater tax compliance and efficient tax administration. The outcome will be 
measured by (i) the higher number of registered tax filers; (ii) reduced time required for tax filing 
management, including appeal and compensation; and (iii) lower tax collection cost. 
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  To achieve the impact and outcome, the TA will (i) develop and install a web-based 
automated  RAMIS;  (ii)  deliver  training  programs  for  tax  officials  and  a  public  awareness 
program  for  taxpayers;  and  (iii)  conduct  a  study  on  revenue  policies  and  the  regulatory 
framework for expanding the revenue base and streamlining revenue administration.10 
 
12.  Output 1: Revenue administration management information system established 
and activated. Detailed features of output 1 will include  
 
(i)  simplified taxpayer registration that will provide unique tax identification numbers, 
taxpayer registration, and issuance of certificates;  
(ii)  improved  collection  management  through  billing  and  payment  processing, 
delinquency  monitoring,  and  collections  (including  nonpayment  risk  rating, 
identification of defaulters, and payment monitoring);  
(iii)  high taxpayer compliance through online and self services for filing returns and 
documents for achieving compliance, assessment and audit, and appeals to 
address taxpayer grievances related to, among others, assessments and audits;  
(iv)  strengthened tax administration using performance analysis, revenue forecasting, 
regulations and notices, accounting, and document management;  
(v)  facilitated refund processing and compensation, including prefiling notice service, 
inputs processing, error validation and correction, and tax-due determination;  
(vi)  creation of a taxpayer database with tax identification numbers as a prerequisite 
for the implementation of an e-filing system; 
(vii)  online data exchange between the DRC and the Department of Public Accounts; 
and e-tax filing with a provision for inclusion of digital signatures in future scaled-
up operations.  
 
13.  The cost of the project management specialists (e-governance specialist and system 
engineering  and  network  specialist)  who  will assist  the DRC  during  the  implementation  of 
RAMIS and with procurement of hardware for RAMIS will be financed from ADB’s TA for 
Strengthening Public Management.11 
 
                                                 
9  Room in a government’s budget which allows it to provide resources for a desired purpose without jeopardizing the 
sustainability of its financial position or the stability of the economy. 
10 RAMIS will capture collection management as well as data on collection of personal income tax, corporate income 
tax, business income tax, and sales tax. Nontax revenue and customs duty will not be included; however, to give a 
complete picture of total revenue collected at any point and because of the substantial size of the customs duty, 
RAMIS will provide details of the collection of customs duty and nontax revenue. 
11 ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Bhutan for Strengthening Public Management. Manila (TA 
7724-BHU). More than $300,000 has been allocated for the cost and, of this, about $200,000 has been earmarked 
for procurement of equipment.

4     
14.  Output 2: Training programs on revenue administration management information 
system and public awareness program. The implementation of RAMIS is expected to lead to 
a more accountable system for increasing revenue collection by (i) enabling access to timely 
and accurate information, (ii) tracking collections, and (iii) enabling the DRC to reach out to 
taxpayers more efficiently and effectively. Training will be provided to government officials in the 
technical aspects of a revenue administration system, as well as to enhance their capacity for 
change management and to increase staff knowledge on rolling out new taxes through the 
introduction  of  information  and  communication  technology–enabled  tools.  Subsequently,  an 
awareness program will be conducted to increase public understanding of the RAMIS and of 
how higher revenue resulting from its implementation enables the government to address social 
and economic priorities. At the onset of the TA, the consulting firm will conduct consultations 
with representatives of the public and private sectors to secure their support for the TA.12  
 
15.  Output 3: Study on revenue policies and regulatory framework. The TA will also be 
used to (i) broaden the revenue base, improve revenue compliance, and explore additional tax 
and nontax revenue sources in the future; (ii) review relevant legal and regulatory frameworks 
for introducing new tax and nontax revenues; (iii) improve the efficiency of revenue collection 
through the introduction of a streamlined administration process; and (iv) increase accountability 
and transparency in internal governance systems by reducing human intervention in revenue 
administration. 
 
16.  In terms of impact, the TA assumes that the government will remain committed to tax 
reforms during TA implementation. Changes in the leadership of key government agencies 
could reduce support for TA activities. At the outcome level, the TA assumes that the selected 
government officials will effectively manage the tax filing system that will be developed with ADB 
support and acceptance of the new system will be widespread. The risk at this level includes 
delayed  implementation  of  RAMIS  because  of  resistance  from  tax  officials  and  a  lack  of 
acceptance among stakeholders. To mitigate these risks, the TA includes training of officials 
and public awareness programs during implementation.  
 
17.  In  terms  of  outputs,  the  TA  assumes  that  the  demand  by  government  officials  for 
improving their tax management skills will be sufficient and that they will be able to attend 
training programs. Another assumption is that the selected vendor understands and addresses 
the functional and technical requirements in the solution. The main risks at this level are that the 
system used is complicated and that end users may not fully understand how to use the RAMIS 
correctly in line with the design and requirements. To mitigate these risks, the implementation 
arrangements will include the engagement of a change management expert and the provision of 
proper training by the vendor.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund, and administered by 
ADB. The financing will cover the cost of consultants who will implement the TA including the 
training and public awareness programs. The government will contribute $50,000 in the form of 
staff remuneration, office space for consultants, and facilities for training programs. Detailed 
cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
                                                 
12 The public awareness campaign will be developed by the consulting firm in consultation with the DRC to ensure 
sufficient understanding and usage of the Information and Communication Technology (ICT) system by taxpayers. 
The firm will also deploy an IT security specialist to protect the system’s sensitive personal information and 
financial data.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The DRC will be both the executing agency and the implementing agency. The DRC will 
chair a project steering committee comprising officials from the Department of Public Accounts 
and  the  Department  of  Budget  as  well  as  the  DRC.  The  DRC  will  establish  a  project 
management unit (PMU) and appoint a project director as the focal point and principal liaison 
with ADB. The project director and PMU team will work full time. The PMU team will comprise 
system analysts, programmers, and revenue business engineers.  
 
20.  A consulting firm and an individual consultant will be engaged in accordance with ADB 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The consulting firm 
will  be  recruited  using  the  quality-based  selection  method  because  (i) the  assignment  is 
complex and highly specialized; (ii) the outputs of RAMIS constitute a pillar of the government’s 
revenue administration architecture and will require regular upgrades in future generations of 
reforms; and (iii) the need for greater expertise in these areas, which are still being piloted, 
poses risks for the effective achievement of RAMIS tasks; and (iv) the project could fail if the 
best consultants are not selected, and if coordination with ADB’s TA for Strengthening Public 
Management is not strong (footnote 10). Interested firms will be asked to submit simplified 
technical  proposals.  International  (24  person-months)  and  national  (16  person-months) 
consultants will be needed under the consulting firm. The international individual consultant (2 
person-months) will be recruited using the individual selection method. Disbursements will be 
made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time).  
 
21.  A workshop will be held and a booklet on best practices and lessons learned in the TA 
will be published in Bhutan. The workshop and publication will be organized with technical 
inputs from ADB staff.13 
 
22.  The TA will start on 1 November 2011 and end on 31 January 2015.14 The government 
and ADB will periodically review the TA implementation. The reviews will include evaluation of 
project scope, implementation arrangements, progress against the milestones, and results of 
capacity building measures. Specifically, the government and ADB staff will assess and provide 
feedback on progress reports by the PMU and the consultants. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of Bhutan to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund for Developing a Revenue Administration Management Information System, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
13 TA reports will be made publicly available on the ADB website.  
14 This period is a maximum estimate and can be reduced to 3 years subject to the program customization progress. 
Consultants hired under ADB’s TA for Strengthening Public Management (TA 7724-BHU) are preparing bid 
documents for recruitment of the implementation partner, and that may speed up the implementation of RAMIS.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consulting Firm 
 
1.  The  scope  of  work  of  the  consulting  firm  will  have  four  components:  (i)  “as-is” 
assessment, covering a detailed study of the current situation at the DRC including overall 
organization vision and direction toward the  strategic change planned through RAMIS and 
current business processes, systems, acts and regulations, and capacity of people at the DRC 
to understand how tax administration is carried out in the current scenario; (ii) requirements 
definition, covering analysis of issues and complexities in existing environment, identification of 
global best practices applicable for tax administration, reengineering of the business processes, 
definition  of  to-be  business  processes  and  preparation  of  the  functional  requirement 
specifications  for  the  application  software  to  be  developed  and  implemented  for  RAMIS, 
assessment of technical requirements specifications for the IT infrastructure for RAMIS. etc.; (iii) 
development of RAMIS, covering system design and development based on the requirements 
defined and agreed for RAMIS with the DRC, testing of the developed system, and making the 
system ready for use and operations by the DRC; and (iv) implementation of RAMIS, including 
digitization and migration of taxpayer records, training of DRC staff and taxpayers in RAMIS 
usage and operations, system integration, and launch of RAMIS. 
 
2.  These output-based terms of reference are the master scope of work that the consulting 
firm must deliver irrespective of whether all tasks are explicitly mentioned or not. Indicative 
resource  requirements  and  activities  are  given  below  for  further  elaboration.  The  following 
positions may be considered as standard team composition, although they may still change 
depending on the findings of the project director and ADB at technical assistance (TA) inception.   
 
3.  E-tax  system  specialist  and  team  leader  (international,  5  person-months).  The 
specialist will have at least 15 years’ experience in information systems development with strong 
exposure to tax administration systems. The specialist will have at least a master’s degree in 
information technology (IT) or computer science, or a relevant discipline. The specialist will 
preferably have worked previously in the development of tax administration systems for amounts 
of $2 million. The specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  review and finalize the implementation schedule;  
(ii)  review the business process study, mapping, and reengineering;  
(iii)  prepare the system requirement specification or business blueprint;  
(iv)  prepare the system design document;  
(v)  lead the development and customization of application software for RAMIS; 
(vi)  lead in testing the application software, and guide the team in installing and 
implementing the application software;  
(vii)  assist the government in finalizing the as-is study and functionality analysis for 
introducing an internally acceptable e-tax filing system based on the inputs from 
the e-governance specialist recruited under the ADB TA for Strengthening Public 
Management;1 
(viii)  guide the team to develop the architecture definition and design for RAMIS;  
(ix)  ensure the final output of RAMIS is a system with the functions of (a) taxpayer 
registration, (b) collection management and e-filing, (c) tax data management, 
(d) taxpayer compliance, and (e) returns processing;

(xiii)  provide dedicated training in coordination with the team leader and the capacity-

6.  Capacity-building and change management expert (international, 2 person-months). 
The expert will have at least 10 years of experience in organizational change management and 
capacity  building  associated  with  business  transformation,  preferably  in  the  context  of 
organization-wide IT initiatives. The expert will have a master’s degree in human resource 
management or a related discipline and will have experience in developing change management 
strategies and in managing human resources successfully through the change. The expert will 
perform the following tasks: 
(i)  in consultation with the DRC and team leader, undertake an assessment of 
change readiness, identify the change management interventions required, and 
draw up a change management plan; 
(ii)  support implementation of the change management plan; 
(iii)  conduct a change management feasibility study, prepare a capacity-building plan, 
identify specific sets of skills for training, and propose a curriculum for different 
levels of government officials; 
(iv)  conduct change management training of selected officials of relevant agencies; 
and 
(v)  analyze users’ feedback on training and change management processes and 
take appropriate action. 
 
7.  International System developer (international, 8 person-months). The developer will 
have at least 5 years of experience in designing software systems in the development platform 
proposed  for  RAMIS  development  and  implementation.  The  developer  will  have  at  least a 
bachelor’s degree in IT or computer science, or a relevant discipline. The developer will perform 
the following tasks: 
(i)  conduct the requirements study and documentation; 
(ii)  prepare software requirement specifications and develop application software in 
consultation with the team leader and other experts; 
(iii)  conduct documentation of the software and unit testing of the software; 
(iv)  implement RAMIS and train the users; and 
(v)  fix bugs in RAMIS. 
 
8.  Testing  and  quality  assurance  specialist  (international,  1  person-month).  The 
specialist  will  have  at  least  5  years’  experience  in  assessment  and  definition  of  testing 
requirements for the software, development of software testing scope and strategy, preparation 
of the traceability matrix, test plans, conducting testing, and documentation of test results. The 
specialist will have at least a master’s degree in IT or computer science, or a relevant discipline. 
The specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  study the software requirement specifications; 
(ii)  develop the testing scope and strategy, and testing plans; and 
(iii)  test and document the test results.
